On Paradise, Slow Club remain a double-sided duo equally capable of heartbreaking folk ballads or brash indie pop, but their second album also shows how much theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve grown from the Yeah, So? days. They donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t waste any time showing how much bigger and bolder they sound: the audacious opening track Ã¢â‚¬Å“Two CousinsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ pairs Charles Watson and Rebecca Taylor's twinned vocals with bright keyboards, adding a cheery tinge to plaintive concerns like Ã¢â‚¬Å“where your heart goes when you die.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ They follow that with Ã¢â‚¬Å“If WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re Still Alive,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ which is all call-and-response vocals and crashing rhythms that are anything but slow. Indeed, the duoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pop side really takes flight on Paradise, whether itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the stomping Ã¢â‚¬Å“BeginnersÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ or the full-on joyous Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Dog,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ which boasts staccato guitars that recall the Walkmen at their boldest. Yet Watson and Taylor keep everything that made Yeah, So? such a special debut. Meanwhile, Watson gets close enough to break your heart on the cozy Ã¢â‚¬Å“Horses Jumping,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ which moves from a simple acoustic ballad into something more expansive as he sings Ã¢â‚¬Å“good love is hard to regret/when you know it was real.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Though Slow Club can make rainy day music with the best of them, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s always a silver lining to their songs, no matter how sad they get. Polished yet heartfelt, Paradise finds Slow Club shoring up their strengths and exploring new territory with equal confidence.
